body: [ONNX Imputer](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/master/docs/Operators-ml.md#aionnxmlimputer) does not support strings. That's why the converter does not support strings either. The change is not a simple one. Is this something urgent?

@xadupre ah, I didn't know that, that explains it.

If there are alternatives to using an imputer with string (it's followed by an ordinal encoder in the pipeline, so maybe there are ways to invert them? To be investigated). If not then this would be really useful in the short term yes :)
Does it mean that we would need to go through a new version of the onnx spec and its support also by the runtime?

Anyway, I will investigate the option above before anything :)

Thanks
One option would to decompose SimpleImputer(string) into SimpleImputer(int) + LabelEncoder. That needs a code change. I'll see what I can do about it.

issue.title: Support missing string values with SimpleImputer

repository.name: sklearn-onnx
repository.description: Convert scikit-learn models and pipelines to ONNX

body:
Hey @xadupre, it has been some time, and there is still one thing that does not work: when I use `None` as the value for `missing_values`:
```
SimpleImputer(missing_values=None, strategy='most_frequent')
```

I get this error:
```
NotImplementedError: The converter is implemented when the missing values are string not <class 'NoneType'>.
```
I get the same error as @victornoel

This unit test shows that this case should be supported: https://github.com/onnx/sklearn-onnx/blob/master/tests/test_sklearn_imputer_converter.py#L143. It is possible to get a code sample to understand what the differences are?

@xadupre That unit test uses `missing_values=""` but the error pops up when `missing_values=None`

I can replicate the error with the following setup:

**Environment**
```
scikit-learn==0.24.1
onnx==1.9.0
onnxruntime==1.9.0
```

**Code** - this is a simplified version of the unit test (I just quickly put all the code in the local file). 

```python
import onnx
from onnxruntime import InferenceSession
from onnxruntime import __version__ as ort_version
from skl2onnx import __max_supported_opset__ as max_opset
import unittest
from distutils.version import StrictVersion
import numpy as np
import sklearn

try:
    from sklearn.preprocessing import Imputer
except ImportError:
    Imputer = None

try:
    from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer
except ImportError:
    # changed in 0.20
    SimpleImputer = None

from skl2onnx import convert_sklearn
from skl2onnx.common.data_types import (
    FloatTensorType, Int64TensorType, StringTensorType)

def max_onnxruntime_opset():
    """
    See `Versioning.md
    <https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/
    master/docs/Versioning.md>`_.
    """
    vi = StrictVersion(ort_version.split('+')[0])
    if vi >= StrictVersion("1.9.0"):
        return 15
    if vi >= StrictVersion("1.8.0"):
        return 14
    if vi >= StrictVersion("1.6.0"):
        return 13
    if vi >= StrictVersion("1.3.0"):
        return 12
    if vi >= StrictVersion("1.0.0"):
        return 11
    if vi >= StrictVersion("0.4.0"):
        return 10
    if vi >= StrictVersion("0.3.0"):
        return 9
    return 8

import os
TARGET_OPSET = int(
    os.environ.get(
        'TEST_TARGET_OPSET',
        min(max_onnxruntime_opset(),
            min(max_opset,
                onnx.defs.onnx_opset_version()))))


class TestSklearnImputerConverter(unittest.TestCase):

    def _check_outputs_strings(self, model, model_onnx, data):
        idata = {'input': np.array(data).astype(np.str_)}
        sess = InferenceSession(model_onnx.SerializeToString())
        res = sess.run(None, idata)[0]
        exp = model.transform(data)
        if list(exp.ravel()) != list(res.ravel()):
            raise AssertionError(
                "Unexpected output expected %r != %r." % (exp, res))

    @unittest.skipIf(SimpleImputer is None,
                     reason="SimpleImputer changed in 0.20")
    @unittest.skipIf(
        StrictVersion(sklearn.__version__) < StrictVersion('0.24'),
        reason="SimpleImputer does not support strings")
    def test_simple_imputer_string_inputs_int_mostf(self):
        model = SimpleImputer(
            strategy="most_frequent", fill_value="nan", missing_values="")
        data = [["s1", "s2"], ["", "s3"], ["s7", "s6"], ["s8", ""]]
        model.fit(data)
        model_onnx = convert_sklearn(
            model, "scikit-learn simple imputer",
            [("input", StringTensorType([None, 2]))],
            target_opset=TARGET_OPSET)
        self.assertIn("ai.onnx.ml", str(model_onnx))
        self.assertTrue(model_onnx.graph.node is not None)
        self.assertEqual(len(model_onnx.graph.output), 1)
        self._check_outputs_strings(model, model_onnx, data)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()
```

You can get the following result by running it.

**IF  `missing_values=""` THEN** 

```
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.028s

OK
```

**IF `missing_values=None` THEN** 

```
E
======================================================================
ERROR: test_simple_imputer_string_inputs_int_mostf (__main__.TestSklearnImputerConverter)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:/Users/gseif/AppData/Roaming/JetBrains/PyCharmCE2020.2/scratches/scratch_7.py", line 81, in test_simple_imputer_string_inputs_int_mostf
    target_opset=TARGET_OPSET)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\convert.py", line 186, in convert_sklearn
    remove_identity=not intermediate, verbose=verbose)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\common\_topology.py", line 1363, in convert_topology
    topology.convert_operators(container=container, verbose=verbose)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\common\_topology.py", line 1200, in convert_operators
    self.call_converter(operator, container, verbose=verbose)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\common\_topology.py", line 1015, in call_converter
    conv(self.scopes[0], operator, container)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\common\_registration.py", line 26, in __call__
    return self._fct(*args)
  File "C:\Users\gseif\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\skl2onnx\operator_converters\imputer_op.py", line 31, in convert_sklearn_imputer
    "are string not %r." % type(op.missing_values))
NotImplementedError: The converter is implemented when the missing values are string not <class 'NoneType'>.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.004s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

I see. This was not implemented on purpose because ONNX is strongly typed. If the input type is string, the missing value must be encoded as a string. The error message may be not clear enough but that's a consequence of ONNX strong types.

@xadupre right, it makes sense from an inference point of view. What would be the way to ensure we can use `None` for `missing_values` (useful for training) while allowing sklearn-onnx to work?

Maybe sklearn-onnx could only use `statistics_` to detect types and not check `missing_values` at all for validation? I'm not sure how feasible it is though :)
